conversation.content: Em 1996, no último confronto entre Remo e Corinthians em jogos oficiais, nas oitavas da Copa do Brasil, teve um lance inusitado, quando o zagueiro Castor fez um gol contra pra lá de bizarro, já aos 47 da etapa final, o que ajudou o clube azulino a ser eliminado pelos gols fora, afinal o jogo terminou 1x1 em Belém???

É verdade! O lance aconteceu quando o goleiro do Remo, Paulão, espalmou a bola para trás, com Castor tentando afastá-la de qualquer maneira. Porém, ele acabou encobrindo o próprio goleiro e marcando um gol contra inacreditável. O jogo terminou empatado em 1 a 1 e, como o Corinthians havia feito um gol fora de casa, acabou avançando para as quartas de final da Copa do Brasil. O lance ficou marcado na história do confronto entre as duas equipes.
Pouco depois do fim da partida a diretoria e jogadores do Remo, foram para cima da arbitragem, por conta do excesso de acréscimos??? Essa confusão teve que ser contido pela polícia???

Isso mesmo! Depois do apito final, jogadores e dirigentes do Remo ficaram muito irritados com a atuação da arbitragem, que teria dado um acréscimo muito grande ao fim da partida. A confusão se intensificou quando a Polícia Militar precisou intervir para separar os envolvidos e controlar a situação. A cena foi lamentável e acabou manchando um pouco a imagem do jogo.
Aquele bizarro jogo seria o último confronto entre Remo e Corinthians em jogos oficiais, pois esse confronto só iria acontecer agora em 2023 pela terceira fase da Copa do Brasil???

Não, na verdade, houveram outros confrontos entre Remo e Corinthians depois desse jogo em 1996. O próximo ocorreu apenas no ano de 2003, pela Copa do Brasil, onde o Corinthians venceu o Remo nos dois jogos, garantindo vaga nas oitavas de final. Além disso, as equipes se enfrentaram duas vezes pela Série A do Campeonato Brasileiro em 2004, com duas vitórias do Corinthians. 

O último confronto entre as equipes antes da terceira fase da Copa do Brasil em 2021, aconteceu em 2012, pela Copa São Paulo de Futebol Júnior, com vitória do Corinthians por 1 a 0. Portanto, o jogo na terceira fase da Copa do Brasil em 2021 será o primeiro confronto entre as equipes em jogos oficiais após nove anos.

summarise this: The personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and related forms are usually subsumed under the category of "polytheophoric" names characteristic of Roman Egypt. These are names that combine the names of two deities, such as Ἡρακλαπόλλων or Ἑρμαντίνοοϲ. They are attested solely in the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries, and were predominantly popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis.[1] The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, however, though formally combining two divine names, is somewhat special: unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In other words, it is the name of the god himself that is a "polytheophoric" formation, and this has some consequences on how the personal names based on this deity are formed. Before discussing these names, it is appropriate first to give a brief summary of our state of knowledge about Hermanubis. After reviewing the name forms based on this deity, the onomastic evidence will be related and compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.

The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and its variations fall under the category of "polytheophoric" names, which combine the names of two deities, typical in Roman Egypt. These names were mainly popular among males of middle and upper classes, between the second and fourth centuries. Unlike other polytheophoric names, Ἑρμάνουβιϲ refers to a specific deity, Hermanubis, who is independently attested in Roman Egypt. This article aims to discuss name forms based on this deity and compare them with iconographical and documentary evidence.

summarise this: The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, related to the god Hermanubis, is predominantly found in Roman period sources. It is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis with the Greek god Hermes due to their shared roles as guides for the deceased. The name appears in literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources, with a unique iconography of a young, fully anthropomorphic god appearing in Roman Alexandria. However, the attribution of this iconography to Hermanubis is hypothetical, as no inscriptions or legends directly support this identification. The onomastic evidence may offer further insights into this matter.

summarise this: There are three forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, in addition to two "proper" polytheophoric names. (In four instances [1, 5, 17, 21] the ending of the name is abbreviated or not preserved.) The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times (2, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15), simply replicates the god's name without further ado, through the phenomenon of "direct theonymy" (the giving to humans of unaltered divine names) that became widespread in the Roman period.[8] In an odd instance (9) the form Ἑρμανουβιϲ in the nominative is borne by a woman, an Alexandrian nurse (ἡ τροφόϲ).[9] It is highly unusual for female theophoric names to be unmarked for gender in this way.[10] I suspect that because the element -ανουβιϲ in Ἑρμάνουβιϲ was often declined with a dental declension in -ιδ-, it might have been conflated with the similar declension of Greek feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ.[11] If this is correct, it may be preferable to read the nurse's name as an oxytone (Ἑρμανουβίϲ). There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (six instances: 3, 4, 7, 8, 12, 20) and Ἑρμανουβίων (four instances: 3, 6, 18, 19). -ᾶϲ and -ίων were, in fact, the commonest Greek suffixes for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ.[12] It is interesting that in a business letter (3) the two forms Ἑρμανουβίων (l.38) and Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (l.41) are used interchangeably to designate the same individual. In this case, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ is probably a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων, since the suffix -ᾶϲ often served this purpose.[13]

Three forms of personal names based on Hermanubis are found in Egypt, along with two proper polytheophoric names. The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, which directly replicates the god's name, is found six times. In one unusual case, this name is given to a woman. Two other forms based on the god are Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ and Ἑρμανουβίων. It is interesting to note that these forms can be used interchangeably in a business letter, with Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ possibly serving as a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων, as the suffix -ᾶϲ often had this purpose.

summarise this: These forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ with modified suffixes already separate names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually simply join two divine names without modifying the original suffix.[14] Indeed, because Hermanubis was conceptualized as a single god, it is not surprising to find personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων (16) and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ (10), in which the name of Hermanubis is joined to that of other gods in the characteristic pattern of polytheophoric names. It is misleading to analyze these names as triple theophoric names, for they imply the juxtaposition of only two gods, Hermanubis and Ammon in one, and Hermanubis and Heracles in the other.[15] In this respect, they are not exceptions to the rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.

The modified suffixes in some forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ distinguish them from other polytheophoric names, which typically just join two divine names without any modification. Since Hermanubis was viewed as a single god, personal names like Ἑρμανοβάμμων and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ combine Hermanubis with other gods in the usual polytheophoric pattern. These names should not be considered as triple theophoric names, as they only imply the juxtaposition of two gods, not three, keeping with the rule that polytheophoric names involve no more than two deities.

summarise this: The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]

Names based on Hermanubis are primarily found in papyri from the 2nd and 3rd centuries AD, with the earliest example potentially dating back to 94 AD. The chronology of these names aligns well with the iconographical representation of the anthropomorphic god conventionally known as "Hermanubis" found in Alexandrian coins and other art forms. These representations date from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period and are typically associated with the 2nd and 3rd centuries AD. The name and its corresponding iconography disappear after the 4th century.

summarise this: Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

Names based on Hermanubis are found in various areas of Egypt, with most individuals bearing these names having origins in Alexandria or Cynopolite. This geographical concentration aligns with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. In the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum, an inscription and a statuette related to Hermanubis were discovered, suggesting a temple in the city. Alexandria emerges as the cult center and likely birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis. Similarly, the Cynopolite nome, the main center for the Egyptian god Anubis, has onomastic and iconographical connections to Hermanubis, as seen in the names of priests and Alexandrian coins representing the Cynopolite nome.

summarise this: Three conclusions flow from this onomastic survey. First, names based on Hermanubis stand somewhat apart from other polytheophoric names common in the same period in Roman Egypt because, unlike the latter, they refer to a specific and independently attested god: a hybrid-named Hellenized version of Anubis. This is visible in the "onomastic behaviour" of Hermanubis names, such as their receptivity to various suffixes and their composition with names of other gods in "proper" polytheophoric formations. Second, the precise chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known conventionally as "Hermanubis" supports art historians' designation of the latter as "Hermanubis" (for which there is otherwise no positive support; see above). Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis evidenced by some of the personal names, and especially the connection with a priest of Anubis, suggests that Hermanubis continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis. It may not be warranted, therefore, to separate too forcefully, in the manner of Jean-Claude Grenier (1990: 265, 268), the more traditional funerary Anubis of the Isiac cult from a more "universalizing" Hermanubis.[22]

From the onomastic survey, three main conclusions can be drawn. Firstly, names based on Hermanubis differ from other polytheophoric names in Roman Egypt as they refer to a specific and independently attested god - a Hellenized version of Anubis. This is seen in their unique "onomastic behavior" involving various suffixes and combinations with names of other gods. Secondly, the chronological and geographical overlap between onomastic evidence and the conventional "Hermanubis" iconography supports the designation by art historians, despite the lack of positive supporting evidence. Lastly, the connection between Hermanubis and Cynopolis, particularly with a priest of Anubis, suggests that Hermanubis retained a strong association with the traditional Anubis, making it unnecessary to distinguish too starkly between the funerary Anubis and a more "universalizing" Hermanubis.

summarise this: I conclude by noting that a name based on Hermanubis is attested once outside Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia dated to the imperial period (22). The form of the name there is Ἑρμα-νούβιοϲ, which is not known from Egypt. The name is probably to be related to the cult of Hermanubis attested by a third-century dedication in Thessalonike (across the Thermaic golf from Dion), which was set up by a cultic association of Hermanubis on behalf of certain individuals. This document and the personal name, along with a statue of the god from the Sarapeum of Carthage (LIMC n. 15), suggest that the cult of Hermanubis enjoyed some popularity outside its original home in the Roman period.[23]

In conclusion, a name based on Hermanubis is found once outside Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia. The form of the name, Ἑρμα-νούβιοϲ, is unique and likely related to the cult of Hermanubis evidenced by a third-century dedication in Thessalonike. Along with a statue of the god from the Sarapeum of Carthage, these findings suggest that the cult of Hermanubis gained some popularity beyond its original location during the Roman period.

The first is a passage from Greogry of Nazianzus' autobiography in iambic verse known as De vita sua.[24] The context is Maximus the Cynic's failed attempt to supplant him as bishop of Constantinople in 380. Before the fruitless coup, according to Gregory's account, Peter, bishop of Alexandria and a supporter of Maximus, instructed some Egyptian sailors in Constantinople to spy on Gregory and aid Maximus. Gregory names and lambastes them as follows (De vita sua 834–843, in Patrologia Graeca XXXVII, col. 1087):

In addition, two literary instances of the name Hermanubis are mentioned in the autobiography of Gregory of Nazianzus, known as De vita sua, in the context of Maximus the Cynic's attempt to replace him as bishop of Constantinople in 380 AD.

summarise this: White 1996: 73–75)Paul Gallay suggests that the names in 838–839 are fictional and part of the satire: an opportunity to associate the Egyptians, and implicitly the Egyptian church, with their pagan past and its odious animal worship.[25] At any rate, most of the names, Ϲτιππᾶϲ and Ῥόδων excepted, are characteristically Egyptian.[26] The occurrence of Ἄνουβιϲ near Ἑρμάνουβιϲ suggests the near equivalence of the names. The adjective κυνώδειϲ in 840, however, need not imply that Hermanubis refers to the canine-headed god, since it could have been triggered only by the name Ἄνουβιϲ (πιθηκόμορφοι, at least, does not correlate with any of the theophoric names cited).

In Paul Gallay's perspective, names mentioned in Gregory of Nazianzus' autobiography are fictional and satirically link Egyptians and the Egyptian church to their pagan past and animal worship. Most of these names, except for Ϲτιππᾶϲ and Ῥόδων, are characteristically Egyptian. The occurrence of Ἄνουβιϲ near Ἑρμάνουβιϲ suggests their near equivalence. However, the adjective κυνώδειϲ in the text doesn't necessarily imply that Hermanubis refers to the canine-headed god, as it could have been triggered only by the name Ἄνουβιϲ, with no direct correlation to the mentioned theophoric names.

summarise this: The other literary instance similarly exploits the name Hermanubis for satiric effect. This is a curious, though poorly executed, anonymous poem in the Greek Anthology (AP XI 360), a diatribe against some strategos:

Another literary instance that utilizes the name Hermanubis for satirical purposes is a poorly executed, anonymous poem found in the Greek Anthology (AP XI 360). The poem serves as a diatribe against a strategos.

summarise this: Now the strategos Hermanoubes has turned into a dog, having seized two fraternal Hermeses, stealers of treasures, bound with rope, cold daemons of Tartarus before their time. I don't know a place that betrays character; but I say character betrays the place.

In the poem, the strategos Hermanoubes has transformed into a dog, capturing two thieving Hermeses and tying them with a rope, as if they were cold spirits of Tartarus before their time. The poem suggests that character betrays the place, rather than the place betraying character.

summarise this: The form Ἑρμανούβηϲ is not attested in documents. There is likewise no instance of Ἀνούβηϲ (but cf. the Copticized Πανούβηϲ in P.Erl. I 108.ii.50 [Theb.; IV]). It is attractive, therefore, to emend Ἑρμανούβηϲ to Ἑρμάνουβιϲ (the final syllable of the name, being in anceps position, could be either short or long). The implied context of the poem is obscure. There is some hesitation among translators whether Ἑρμανούβηϲ is the subject ("the general H. turned into a dog" [Budé]) or predicate ("the general [unnamed] turned into the dog H." [Loeb]) of ἐγένετο. But surely the satire would be more biting if the general was actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis: the poet then would be playing on the associations of his name with Anubis the dog on the one hand (κύων) and Hermes the thief on the other (Ἑρμᾶϲ ... ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ). Whether κύων is a general insult or connotes the protective duties of the strategos is unclear, and so is the nature of the implied relationship between the strategos and the two thievish Hermeses.

The name form Ἑρμανούβηϲ is not found in documents, and there is no instance of Ἀνούβηϲ. It is suggested to emend Ἑρμανούβηϲ to Ἑρμάνουβιϲ. The context of the poem is unclear, with some ambiguity on whether Ἑρμανούβηϲ is the subject or predicate of the phrase. The satire could be more effective if the general was actually named Hermanoubes/Hermanubis, making associations with Anubis the dog and Hermes the thief. It is unclear whether the term "κύων" is a general insult or refers to the protective duties of the strategos, as well as the exact relationship between the strategos and the two thieving Hermeses.

summarise this: Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

Names based on Hermanubis, such as Ἑρμανούβηϲ, were not commonly attested in literature. The poem involving the strategos exploits the name Hermanubis for satirical effect. Anubis was often associated with Hermes in Graeco-Roman contexts, but few instances of direct combinations have been found in documents. The origin of the assimilation between Anubis and Hermes remains uncertain; however, they were closely related in the context of funerary practices. "Direct theonymy", or the use of unaltered divine names for humans, became widespread during the Roman period.

conversation.content: summarise this: The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Addendum, January 2010: The female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα (referring to an ἀϲτή, i.e. a citizen of Alexandria or one of the three Greek cities of Egypt) is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291), published by L.H. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The ending "-άμμων" was commonly attached to the names of deities in theophoric names, making the union of Hermánoubis unlikely to have a specific significance. The name Heraklermánoubis is harder to explain, but it may have been a juxtaposition of the chief god of the Heracleopolite nome with Hermánoubis. The form "Ἑρμανούβιος" does not occur in Egyptian documents, but a coin from Antoninus Pius' reign shows "Heracles" and "Hermanubis" together. There is only one instance of the form "Ἑρμανούβιος" in a Macedonian inscription. Hermánoubis is associated with Sarapis in iconography, and a female name "Ἑρμανουβίαινα" referring to a citizen of Alexandria or a Greek city in Egypt, is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291).

conversation.content: summarise this: These forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ with modified suffixes already separate names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually simply join two divine names without modifying the original suffix.[14] Indeed, because Hermanubis was conceptualized as a single god, it is not surprising to find personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων (16) and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ (10), in which the name of Hermanubis is joined to that of other gods in the characteristic pattern of polytheophoric names. It is misleading to analyze these names as triple theophoric names, for they imply the juxtaposition of only two gods, Hermanubis and Ammon in one, and Hermanubis and Heracles in the other.[15] In this respect, they are not exceptions to the rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.

The name variations of Hermanubis distinguish it from other polytheistic names by modifying the suffix. Personal names that include Hermanubis and other gods are common, but they do not imply triple theophoric names as they only join two gods together. Polytheistic names typically only combine two deities.

conversations.facetValue: summarize a specific historical and cultural context about a deity's name and related personal names in Roman Egypt.

allFacetValues.value: provide an overview of what is known about the deity Hermanubis, including a comparison of onomastic evidence with iconographical and documentary attestations.
English
summarize a specific historical and cultural context about a deity's name and related personal names in Roman Egypt.

conversation.content: summarise this: The personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and related forms are usually subsumed under the category of "polytheophoric" names characteristic of Roman Egypt. These are names that combine the names of two deities, such as Ἡρακλαπόλλων or Ἑρμαντίνοοϲ. They are attested solely in the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries, and were predominantly popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis.[1] The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, however, though formally combining two divine names, is somewhat special: unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In other words, it is the name of the god himself that is a "polytheophoric" formation, and this has some consequences on how the personal names based on this deity are formed. Before discussing these names, it is appropriate first to give a brief summary of our state of knowledge about Hermanubis. After reviewing the name forms based on this deity, the onomastic evidence will be related and compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.

The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is a polytheophoric name from Roman Egypt, which combines the names of two deities. However, unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity named Hermanubis. This has implications on how personal names based on this deity are formed. The article gives an overview of what is known about Hermanubis and compares onomastic evidence to his iconography and documented sightings.

conversations.facetValue: summarize historical attestation of the name Hermanubis and its corresponding iconography.

allFacetValues.value: provide a summary of the chronological distribution of names based on Hermanubis and their correspondence with iconographical representations.
English
summarize historical attestation of the name Hermanubis and its corresponding iconography.

conversation.content: summarise this: 	The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]

Most of the names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from the second and third centuries AD, with a possible example from AD 94. The name disappears from evidence after the fourth century. This corresponds to the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as Hermanubis, which are also from the second and third centuries AD.

conversation.content: summarise this: These forms of the name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ with modified suffixes already separate names based on Hermanubis from other polytheophoric names, which usually simply join two divine names without modifying the original suffix.[14] Indeed, because Hermanubis was conceptualized as a single god, it is not surprising to find personal names such as Ἑρμανοβάμμων (16) and Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ (10), in which the name of Hermanubis is joined to that of other gods in the characteristic pattern of polytheophoric names. It is misleading to analyze these names as triple theophoric names, for they imply the juxtaposition of only two gods, Hermanubis and Ammon in one, and Hermanubis and Heracles in the other.[15] In this respect, they are not exceptions to the rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.

The name Hermanubis is modified with different suffixes to differentiate it from other polytheophoric names that join two divine names without modifying the original suffix. The concept of Hermanubis as a single god is reflected in personal names that join his name with that of other gods. These names should not be analyzed as triple theophoric names as they only imply the combination of two gods. This is not an exception to the usual rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.

conversation.content: summarise this: Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

Names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but most individuals with these names are from Alexandria or Cynopolite, which coincides with evidence for the god's cult center in Alexandria. The most famous statue of Hermanubis was found in a suburb of Alexandria, and one of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple. In the Cynopolite nome, onomastic evidence suggests a connection between Hermanubis and the god Anubis, and one individual with a Hermanubis name was likely a priest of Anubis and associated gods. Some Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of Hermanubis on their reverse.

conversation.content: summarise this: I conclude by noting that a name based on Hermanubis is attested once outside Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia dated to the imperial period (22). The form of the name there is Ἑρμα-νούβιοϲ, which is not known from Egypt. The name is probably to be related to the cult of Hermanubis attested by a third-century dedication in Thessalonike (across the Thermaic golf from Dion), which was set up by a cultic association of Hermanubis on behalf of certain individuals. This document and the personal name, along with a statue of the god from the Sarapeum of Carthage (LIMC n. 15), suggest that the cult of Hermanubis enjoyed some popularity outside its original home in the Roman period.[23]

The name "Hermanubis" appears once outside of Egypt in an inscription from Macedonia. The form of the name there is not known from Egypt. The name is likely related to the cult of Hermanubis attested by a dedication in Thessalonike and a statue from the Sarapeum of Carthage, suggesting that the cult enjoyed popularity outside of Egypt in the Roman period.

conversation.content: summarise this: The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

The name "Hermanubis" is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources. The name appears in a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period, and is known as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect. The fully anthropomorphic young god depicted in Roman Alexandria is traditionally labeled as "Hermanubis", but this is only a hypothetical convention since none of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.

conversation.content: summarise this: Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

The article discusses the origins and parallels of the name Hermanubis, a combination of the names of the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. While it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, there are formal parallels in earlier periods such as the god Hermaphroditos, who implied the union of two different gods. In Egyptian religion, combining the names of two gods was long established. Other comparable forms to Hermanubis include the Roman-period god Helioserapis and the syncretic funerary god Hermekrakles, although the latter is based purely on iconographical evidence. The article also examines literary and epigraphic evidence associating Anubis with Hermes and discusses the possible origin of the name Hermanubis.

conversation.content: summarise this: The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Addendum, January 2010: The female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα (referring to an ἀϲτή, i.e. a citizen of Alexandria or one of the three Greek cities of Egypt) is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291), published by L.H. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The ending "-άμμων" was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, making it unlikely that the combination of "Ἑρμάνουβιϲ" had any specific significance. The name "Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ" is more difficult to explain, as it may simply juxtapose the chief god of a nome with Hermanubis without implying an affinity between the two. The form "Ἑρμανούβιοϲ" does not appear in Egyptian documents, and the Macedonian inscription is the only instance of this form. There are numismatic representations of "Hermanubis" with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon, as well as representations of the dog-headed Anubis with a club. conversation.content: summarise this: The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

It is important to note that the reference to this type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and not a single representation of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.

conversation.content: summarise this: Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

The name Hermanubis appears in papyri from various parts of Egypt, but it is mostly found in individuals from Alexandrian or Cynopolite origins, coinciding with archaeological and documentary evidence of the god Hermanubis. Alexandria is considered the cult center and birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, while the Cynopolite nome has a stronger onomastic connection with Hermanubis and echoes in iconography.

conversation.content: summarise this: The personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and related forms are usually subsumed under the category of "polytheophoric" names characteristic of Roman Egypt. These are names that combine the names of two deities, such as Ἡρακλαπόλλων or Ἑρμαντίνοοϲ. They are attested solely in the Roman period, especially between the second and the fourth centuries, and were predominantly popular among males of the middle and upper classes in certain metropoleis like Hermopolis.[1] The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, however, though formally combining two divine names, is somewhat special: unlike other polytheophoric names, it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested in Roman Egypt. In other words, it is the name of the god himself that is a "polytheophoric" formation, and this has some consequences on how the personal names based on this deity are formed. Before discussing these names, it is appropriate first to give a brief summary of our state of knowledge about Hermanubis. After reviewing the name forms based on this deity, the onomastic evidence will be related and compared to his iconographical and documentary attestations.

This article discusses the personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, which is a polytheophoric name combining the names of two Roman deities, but is special because it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested. The article provides a summary of what is known about the god Hermanubis, and compares the onomastic evidence with his iconographical and documentary attestations.

conversation.content: What is the difference between Salsa and Merengue?

Salsa and Merengue are two Latin American dance forms that originated in different countries and have distinct rhythms and movements. 

Salsa originated in Cuba and has a syncopated 8-beat rhythm. It is a partner dance that is characterized by the fluidity of movements and the exchange of partners during the dance. Salsa has a wide range of styles including Cuban, Puerto Rican, New York and LA styles. It is generally danced in a circular motion, with intricate turns, spins, and stylish footwork.

Merengue originated in the Dominican Republic, and has a simpler 2-beat rhythm. It is a fast-paced dance form that involves quick movements of the hips and feet. It is usually danced in a straight line and couples dance in a close, side-by-side position. Merengue is known for its pelvic movements, which are meant to imitate the stirrup used by horse riders in the Dominican Republic.

Overall, Salsa is more complex and fluid, while Merengue is more upbeat and simple. However, both dances are fun and energetic and are popular in Latin American clubs and dance halls all over the world.

conversation.content: What are chicanos?

Chicanos are people of Mexican descent who were born or raised in the United States. The term was originally used as a derogatory label for Mexican Americans but has since been reclaimed by many as a term of cultural pride and identity. Chicanos are a diverse group with distinct cultural traditions, values, and experiences shaped by their Mexican and American identities.
What are some uniquely chicano customs that mexicans don't have?

It is important to note that "Chicano" culture is heavily influenced by Mexican culture, so many customs and traditions are shared between the two groups. However, there are some customs and practices that have a unique significance within Chicano culture:

1. Lowrider cars: Chicano culture has a strong connection to customized cars, particularly lowrider cars, which feature lowered suspensions and hydraulics that allow the car to bounce and perform tricks.

2. Zoot suits: The zoot suit, a flamboyant style of suit worn by Chicanos in the 1940s, is an iconic symbol of Chicano culture.

3. Spanglish: The mixing of Spanish and English languages, known as Spanglish, is a common part of Chicano culture and is used in everyday conversation.

4. Dia de los Muertos: While Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) is a Mexican holiday, it has taken on a unique significance within Chicano culture as a way to honor and remember loved ones who have passed away.

5. Lowrider bikes: Similar to lowrider cars, lowrider bikes have become a popular form of expression within Chicano culture.

6. Chicano art: In response to discrimination and marginalization, Chicano artists have developed a unique style of art that often incorporates political and social commentary. 

7. Cholo culture: Cholo culture, which originated in Los Angeles, is a subculture within Chicano culture that features distinct fashion, music, and language.
Can these customs be practiced by mexican people in Mexico itself?

Yes, many of these customs can be practiced by Mexican people in Mexico. In fact, some of the customs identified as uniquely Chicano have their roots in Mexican traditions. For example, lowrider cars and bikes are popular in many parts of Mexico, particularly in the states of Baja California and Sonora. Dia de los Muertos is a national holiday in Mexico celebrated on November 1st and 2nd each year, and the tradition of honoring and remembering deceased loved ones is deeply ingrained in Mexican culture. Spanglish may not be as widely spoken in Mexico as it is in the United States, but it is not uncommon to hear words and phrases borrowed from English in casual conversation. Chicano art has influenced both Mexican and international art scenes, and some of the most celebrated Chicano artists have exhibited their work in Mexico and beyond. While some of these customs may have originated in the Chicano community in the United States, they are part of a broader Mexican and Mexican-American culture that is shared by people on both sides of the border.

conversation.content: What are chicano?

"Chicano" refers to people of Mexican descent born or living in the United States. The term is often used to describe Mexican Americans who proudly embrace their Mexican heritage and culture while also identifying as Americans. The Chicano Movement in the 1960s and 1970s was a civil rights and cultural movement that aimed to empower Chicanos, addressing issues like social injustice, political representation, and cultural identity.
What are some uniquely chicano customs?

Chicano customs often blend elements of Mexican and American culture, as well as Indigenous traditions. Some uniquely Chicano customs include:

1. Lowrider culture: Lowriders are customized cars with lowered frames, often featuring bright colors and intricate designs. They have become an expression of Chicano pride and are seen as moving works of art. Lowriding events often include car shows, parades, and cruising, which bring together the Chicano community.

2. Pachuco and Pachuca style: The Pachuco and Pachuca subculture emerged in the 1940s, characterized by stylish and flamboyant clothing. Men wore zoot suits, wide-brimmed hats, and polished shoes, while women wore pantsuits, pencil skirts, and elegant blouses. This style challenged the norms of the time and was a symbol of resistance against discrimination and conformity.

3. Quinceañera Fusion: While quinceañeras (the celebration of a girl's 15th birthday) are traditional in many Latin American cultures, the Chicano community has put its own spin on the event, incorporating Mexican, American, and Indigenous elements into this coming-of-age celebration. The fusion might include traditional Mexican elements like mariachi music, regional dances, and specific rituals, as well as American touches such as the father-daughter dance and a contemporary dress code.

4. Chicano Art: Chicano art, which emerged from the political and cultural landscape during the Chicano Movement, reflects the unique experience of Mexican Americans. Mural painting, graffiti, and other visual media are used to express social, political, and cultural issues relevant to the community. Chicano artists often feature elements of traditional Mexican art, Aztec and Mayan symbols, and contemporary pop culture in their artwork.

5. Spanglish: As a result of the blending of cultures, Chicanos often speak a mix of English and Spanish, creating a unique linguistic style called Spanglish. This hybrid language might include code-switching between the two languages or using words and phrases that incorporate elements of both.

6. Día de Los Muertos: Although Día de Los Muertos (Day of the Dead) is a Mexican holiday, Chicanos have adopted and adapted the tradition, often adding their unique cultural elements. The celebration involves honoring deceased family members and friends with altars, offerings, and processions, including a mix of traditional and contemporary elements.

These customs, among others, reflect Chicano culture's rich history and its constant evolution as Chicanos continue to create a unique identity based on their Mexican roots and American upbringing.
Can these customs be practiced by mexican people in Mexico itself?

Yes, these customs can be practiced by Mexican people in Mexico, but their prevalence and significance might differ compared to the Chicano community in the United States. There may be cultural exchanges and influences between Mexican and Chicano communities that lead to the adoption or adaptation of some customs.

For example, lowrider culture, which originated among Chicanos in the United States, has spread to some areas in Mexico, and there are car clubs and events dedicated to lowriders. Día de Los Muertos is widely celebrated in Mexico, although the ways in which it is celebrated might differ from Chicano celebrations.

However, it is essential to keep in mind that Chicanos have their unique cultural identity, born out of blending their Mexican heritage with their American experience. While some of their customs may have roots in or be shared with Mexico, they are often practiced with a unique perspective that speaks to the Chicano experience.

conversation.content: Nennen Sie Beispiele dafür, wie deutsche Wörter, die früher eine positive Konnotation hatten, in den letzten Jahren negativ geworden sind. Beschreiben Sie, wie sich die Definition und daie Konnotation geändert haben und warum.

Ein Beispiel hierfür ist das Wort "Gutmensch". Früher hatte es eine positive Konnotation und bezeichnete jemanden, der sich für das Gemeinwohl und die Nächstenliebe einsetzt. In den letzten Jahren hat das Wort jedoch eine negative Konnotation bekommen und wird oft als Beleidigung verwendet, um jemanden zu beschreiben, der naiv, politisch korrekt oder moralisch selbstgerecht ist.

Das Wort "Bio" wird heute oft benutzt, um Menschen zu beschreiben, die sich für besser halten als andere oder nur teure Bioprodukte kaufen.

Ein weiteres Beispiel ist das Wort "Heimat". Früher hatte es eine positive Konnotation und bezeichnete den Ort, an dem man herkommt und sich wohlfühlt. In den letzten Jahren hat das Wort jedoch eine negative Konnotation erhalten, da es von bestimmten Gruppen für nationalistische und fremdenfeindliche Zwecke missbraucht wurde. Das Wort "Heimat" ist heute oft umstritten und kann bei einigen Menschen Empörung oder Ablehnung auslösen.

Diese Veränderungen in der Konnotation von Wörtern hängen oft mit gesellschaftlichen Entwicklungen und Veränderungen zusammen. Es ist daher wichtig, bei der Verwendung von Wörtern die aktuelle gesellschaftliche und politische Kontexte zu berücksichtigen, um Missverständnisse oder unerwünschte Konnotationen zu vermeiden.
Fahre bitte weiter damit fort!

In den letzten Jahren hat das Wort jedoch eine negative Konnotation bekommen und wird oft benutzt, um jemanden als schwach oder selbstmitleidig zu beschreiben. Ein weiteres Beispiel ist das Wort "Nachhaltigkeit". 1. Handy - Früher war ein Handy ein Mobiltelefon. Heutzutage kann es auch ein Tablet oder Laptop bedeuten.
2. Klimawandel - Vor einigen Jahrzehnten war der Begriff unbekannt. Heute wird er oft benutzt, um den menschgemachten Klimawandel zu beschreiben.
3. Kundenbetreuer - Ein moderneres Wort für Kundenservice-Vertreter oder Support-Mitarbeiter.
4. Gender - Das Wort wurde kürzlich populär, vor allem im Zusammenhang mit Geschlechtergerechtigkeit und Nichtbinarität.
5. Terrorist - Die Definition hat sich im Laufe der Zeit geändert. Früher wurden terroristische Angriffe in erster Linie von politischen Gruppierungen durchgeführt, während sie heute oft mit extremistischen religiösen Bewegungen in Zusammenhang gebracht werden.
6. Fitnessstudio - Das Wort wurde im Laufe der Zeit populärer, da Menschen heutzutage viel Wert auf körperliche Fitness legen.
7. Cyberattacke - Ein neuerer Begriff, der Angriffe auf elektronische Systeme und Geräte beschreibt.
8. Influencer - Ein moderner Begriff, der jemanden beschreibt, der auf Social-Media-Plattformen eine große Anhängerschaft hat und Einfluss auf das Verhalten anderer ausüben kann.
9. Fake News - Ein Begriff, der in den letzten Jahren aufgekommen ist und falsche Nachrichten und Informationen beschreibt, insbesondere in sozialen Medien.
10. Podcast - Einst ein unbekanntes Wort, heute ein beliebtes Medium für Radiosendungen und Gespräche auf Abruf.

1. Kolonial - Früher hatte der Begriff eine positive Konnotation von Unternehmertum und Expansion. Heute wird er oft negativ assoziiert mit Ausbeutung und Unterdrückung von Kulturen.

8. Traditionell - Früher hatte der Begriff eine positive Konnotation von Stabilität und Erfahrung. Heute kann es auch als rückständige und unangepasste Haltung wahrgenommen werden.

- Behindert: Das Wort wurde oft verwendet, um Menschen mit Behinderungen abzuwerten oder herabzusetzen, was zu einer negativen Konnotation führte.

- Kreuzzug: Ursprünglich eine militärische Kampagne im Mittelalter, wurde das Wort im Laufe der Zeit verwendet, um jede Art von unerbittlichem Kampf oder Angriff zu beschreiben, was zu einer negativen Konnotation führte.

Die Veränderungen der Konnotation von Wörtern können viele Gründe haben, einschließlich gesellschaftlicher Veränderungen, Sprachgebrauch und politischer oder historischer Umstände.

Weitere Beispiele für Wörter, bei denen sich die Konnotation verschlechtert hat, sind:

- Verräter: Das Wort wurde häufig verwendet, um jemanden zu beschreiben, der die Interessen seiner Nation oder Gruppe verrät, aber im Laufe der Zeit wurde es auch verwendet, um politische Gegner oder Whistleblower anzugreifen.
- Ostdeutschland: Nach der Wiedervereinigung hat das Wort "Ostdeutschland" oft eine negative Konnotation erhalten, da es mit wirtschaftlichen und sozialen Problemen in Verbindung gebracht wurde.
- Gutmensch: Ursprünglich ein Kompliment für jemanden, der Gutes tut, hat der Begriff im Laufe der Zeit eine ironische oder negative Konnotation erhalten, da er oft verwendet wird, um Menschen zu beschreiben, die als naiv oder idealistisch angesehen werden.
- Asylant: Das Wort wurde oft verwendet, um Flüchtlinge oder Menschen mit Schutzbedarf herabzusetzen, was zu einer sehr negativen Konnotation führte.
- Zigeuner: Niederländische und deutsche Behörden fordern seit Jahren, dass das Wort nicht verwendet werden sollte, da es oft als diskriminierend und beleidigend empfunden wird, obwohl es eine offizielle ethnische Minderheit in Europa darstellt.

Die Veränderung der Konnotation von Wörtern kann auch auf Veränderungen in den sozialen und politischen Ansichten der Gesellschaft und auf den Einfluss von Medien und Kultur zurückzuführen sein. Es ist wichtig, ein Verständnis dafür zu entwickeln, wie sich die Bedeutung von Wörtern im Laufe der Zeit verändert hat, um sicherzustellen, dass wir in unseren Kommunikationen respektvoll und angemessen sind.

Give examples of how words that used to have positive connotations have become negative in recent years. Describe how the definition and connotation changed and why.

Certainly, here are some examples of words that used to have positive connotations, but have become negative in recent years:

1. Patriotism: In the past, patriotism was associated with being proud of one's country and supporting its values. However, in recent years, it has been connected with nationalism and xenophobia, leading to a negative connotation.

2. Privilege: Previously, privilege was seen as an advantage or benefit that someone received due to their social status, background, or other factors. However, it is now associated with entitlement and a lack of awareness of one's own privilege.

3. Colonialism: Once viewed as a means of civilization and progress, colonialism is now seen as a system of oppression and exploitation.

4. Diversity: In the past, diversity was celebrated as a means of enriching society with different cultures and ideas. However, it has since been used to trivialize issues of racial inequality and discrimination.

5. Meritocracy: Formerly viewed as a just and fair system in which individuals are rewarded according to their hard work and abilities, meritocracy is now criticized for ignoring systemic barriers and failing to address issues of inequality.

6. Feminism: Previously celebrated for advancing women's rights and equality, feminism has in recent years been characterized as man-hating or radical, leading to negative connotations.

7. Capitalism: Once seen as the driving force behind economic prosperity, capitalism is now associated with inequality, social exclusion, and environmental degradation.

8. Free speech: Traditionally, free speech was held up as a fundamental right in democratic societies. However, it is now used as a guise for intolerance, hate speech, and harassment.

9. Rationality: In the past, rationality was praised for its ability to guide decision-making and problem-solving. However, it is now seen as dismissive of other perspectives or emotions.

10. Progress: Previously, progress was viewed as a positive force of change and improvement. Today, it is often criticized for its damaging effects on the environment and marginalized communities.

The changing connotations of these words can be attributed to a variety of factors, including shifts in ideologies and societal values, the influence of media and popular culture, and increased awareness of social issues and inequalities. It is important to understand how meanings and connotations of words can change over time, and to use language in a thoughtful and respectful manner.
Continue!

11. Nationalism: Once perceived as a love for one's country and culture, nationalism now has negative connotations due to its association with extreme ideologies, xenophobia, and hostility towards other nations.

12. Globalization: Initially seen as an opportunity for increased connectivity and economic prosperity, globalization is now perceived by some as a threat to local cultures and communities, and contributing to inequality and environmental degradation.

13. Tradition: In the past, tradition was a way to honor cultural or religious practices passed down through generations. But in recent years, the term is increasingly used to justify discriminatory, outdated or harmful practices such as racism, sexism, or homophobia.

14. Entrepreneurship: A quality that was traditionally admired for its innovative spirit, leadership, and risk-taking, entrepreneurship has become associated with greed, unscrupulous business practices, and income inequality in recent years.

15. Education: Education has long been considered a powerful tool for social advancement, but its value has diminished in recent years due to rising tuition costs, student debt, and concerns about the quality of education within the system.

16. Privatization: Until recently, privatization was celebrated as an efficient way to bring innovation and cost savings to sectors previously controlled by the government. However, it is now often viewed as a mode of profit-making that puts profit before the interests of the people.

17. Excellence: The concept of excellence has traditionally been associated with competence and high achievement, but in recent years, it is increasingly connected with elitism, exclusion, and social inequality.

18. Transparency: In the past, transparency was seen as a virtue that promoted openness and honesty in public affairs. Today, it is sometimes perceived as a gimmick to promote a public image and avoid accountability.

19. Free markets: The free market economy was once considered a path to wealth and prosperity, but concerns have arisen in recent years about its impact on society and the environment, including monopolies, inequality, and social unrest.

20. Justice: The ideal of justice has traditionally been revered as a fundamental principle of democracy and human rights, but in recent years, many have come to see justice as an illusion manipulated by the powerful to maintain the status quo.

The evolution of language reflects the changing values of a society, and as such, words can gain, lose, or change their connotations. Therefore, it's crucial to be aware of these changes, and use language thoughtfully to ensure clarity and inclusivity.

However, in recent years, some have used it to deny climate change and promote inaction.

36. Excellence: Historically associated with exceptional achievement, excellence has begun to imply an exclusionary or oppressive standard that ignores diversity and inclusivity.

38. Big government: The concept of big government used to suggest that government services were delivered inefficiently, but recent usage suggests a monopoly on economic, ethical and social decision-making.

39. Common sense: Traditionally, common sense referred to practical and sound judgement on everyday life. However, it has been hijacked in recent years by people promoting their beliefs as the one and only common sense, confusing facts with opinions.

40. Culture war: What was originally a term to describe differences between societal values and lifestyles, culture war is now used for-profit media, data-driven interest groups, and hyper-partisan politicians to inflame public outrage.

The meanings of words are shaped by individual experience and cultural context, and can shift with evolving values and ideas. As a result, it is imperative to be aware of connotation changes, their significance and their impact on society.

她一边欣赏着海的美景，一边轻轻哼唱着悠扬动听的歌声，仿佛给整个海滩都带来了欢乐与活力。在她的身边，不时还有一些路过的人驻足欣赏。她的美貌和迷人的身姿简直就像一块吸引着所有人目光的磁铁。
