conversation.content: summarise this: Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

The article discusses the origin and significance of Hermanubis, a god in ancient Greek and Egyptian religion. It notes that while it was not common to combine the names of two gods in Greek religion, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in earlier periods. The article also examines the syncretism of Anubis and Hermes, two gods associated with death and transitions, and how their assimilation led to the creation of Hermanubis. The article provides insights from various sources, including literary and epigraphic sources, Egyptian statuettes, and ancient coins. It also discusses the marking of gender in Greek personal names and provides examples.

conversation.content: summarise this: The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Addendum, January 2010: The female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα (referring to an ἀϲτή, i.e. a citizen of Alexandria or one of the three Greek cities of Egypt) is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291), published by L.H. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The suffix -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities appearing in theophoric names, making the addition of Ἑρμάνουβιϲ unlikely to have a specific meaning. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more difficult to explain but could simply represent a combination of the chief god of the Heracleopolite nome and Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ is not found in Egyptian documents and is only found in one Macedonian inscription. Hermanubis is associated with Sarapis in iconography, and there are references to a female citizen of Alexandria with the name Ἑρμανουβίαινα. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis mentioned in one source may also have originated from Alexandria.

conversation.content: summarise this: I conclude by noting that a name based on Hermanubis is attested once outside Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia dated to the imperial period (22). The form of the name there is Ἑρμα-νούβιοϲ, which is not known from Egypt. The name is probably to be related to the cult of Hermanubis attested by a third-century dedication in Thessalonike (across the Thermaic golf from Dion), which was set up by a cultic association of Hermanubis on behalf of certain individuals. This document and the personal name, along with a statue of the god from the Sarapeum of Carthage (LIMC n. 15), suggest that the cult of Hermanubis enjoyed some popularity outside its original home in the Roman period.[23]

The name Hermanubis is found once outside of Egypt in an inscription from Dion in Macedonia. The form of the name there is not known from Egypt, and is likely related to the cult of Hermanubis attested in Thessalonike. This suggests that the cult of Hermanubis was popular outside of its original home in the Roman period.

This passage discusses the origins and parallels of Hermanubis, a syncretic god combining the Egyptian god Anubis and the Greek god Hermes. It notes that while it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, there were similar examples in earlier periods, including the god Hermaphroditos (combining Hermes and Aphrodite) and the Carian god Zeus Osogoa (combining Zeus and Poseidon). The passage also explores the association of Anubis with Hermes in literary and epigraphic sources, and discusses the possible origins of the name Hermanubis.

The name "Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ" is more mysterious and may simply combine the names of the chief god of a specific location with Hermanubis. Representations of "Hermanubis" on coins and in art often show a fusion of aspects of both Hermes and Anubis. The form "Ἑρμανούβιοϲ" is not found in Egyptian documents, only in a Macedonian inscription. There is no clear information on the statuette in LIMC that mentions Hermanubis, but the name "Ἑρμανουβίαινα" has recently been found on an ancient artifact. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis could have originated from Alexandria. Additional sources and translations on this topic are available.

conversation.content: summarise this: The near majority of the names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri of the second and third centuries AD. Possibly the earliest example is on an ostracon dated to AD 94 (1), but the name there is abbreviated and Ἑρμανο(υβίου) is Wilcken's resolution.[16] Otherwise, the next attestations are from the second quarter of the second century. There are overall eight instances from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. One instance is from an inscription dated broadly to the "imperial period." The name disappears from the evidence after the fourth century. What is notable about this chronological distribution is that it corresponds neatly to that of the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known conventionally as "Hermanubis." For example, the great number of Alexandrian coins that show a representation of this type on the reverse range from the reign of Trajan (or possibly as early as Domitian) to the Tetrarchic period. Likewise, the statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs of this god have all been assigned to the second or third century AD.[17]

The name disappears from evidence after the fourth century, which corresponds to the timeline of iconographical representations of "Hermanubis." These representations can be found on Alexandrian coins from the reign of Trajan to the Tetrarchic period, as well as statues, statuettes, and carved reliefs assigned to the second or third century AD.

conversation.content: summarise this: Three conclusions flow from this onomastic survey. First, names based on Hermanubis stand somewhat apart from other polytheophoric names common in the same period in Roman Egypt because, unlike the latter, they refer to a specific and independently attested god: a hybrid-named Hellenized version of Anubis. This is visible in the "onomastic behaviour" of Hermanubis names, such as their receptivity to various suffixes and their composition with names of other gods in "proper" polytheophoric formations. Second, the precise chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known conventionally as "Hermanubis" supports art historians' designation of the latter as "Hermanubis" (for which there is otherwise no positive support; see above). Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis evidenced by some of the personal names, and especially the connection with a priest of Anubis, suggests that Hermanubis continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis. It may not be warranted, therefore, to separate too forcefully, in the manner of Jean-Claude Grenier (1990: 265, 268), the more traditional funerary Anubis of the Isiac cult from a more "universalizing" Hermanubis.[22]

The onomastic survey suggests that Hermanubis names are distinct from other polytheophoric names in Roman Egypt because they refer to a specific and independently attested god. The evidence coincides with the representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god known as "Hermanubis." There is a connection between Hermanubis and Cynopolis, and therefore, it may not be necessary to separate the traditional funerary Anubis from a more universalizing Hermanubis.

conversation.content: summarise this: The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

This resulted in widespread representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes. In Roman Alexandria, a new iconographical type emerged featuring a fully anthropomorphic young god flanked by a dog who held the same attributes as Anubis. This type is traditionally labeled "Hermanubis," but none of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.

conversation.content: summarise this: Geographically, names based on Hermanubis are attested in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but it is important to separate, where possible, the provenance of the papyrus from that of the individuals named therein. When this is done, most of the individuals bearing Hermanubis names for whom we can establish an origin turn out to be Alexandrian or Cynopolite (three instances each). This concentration again coincides with the documentary and archaeological evidence for the god Hermanubis. Thus, in the precinct of the Alexandrian Serapeum an inscription of uncertain date was found (SB I 3482) dedicated to "Hermanubis, great god, who listens to prayers and grants favours" (Ἑρμανούβιδι θεῶι μεγάλωι | ἐπηκόωι καὶ εὐχαρίϲτωι).[18] Not far from this dedication a statuette of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" was discovered.[19] It is in a suburb of Alexandria, in the sanctuary of Ras el-Soda, that the most famous statue of "Hermanubis" was found (LIMC n. 14). One of the Alexandrian coins representing the god shows him standing inside a temple (LIMC nos. 5a, b), which suggests the existence of such an edifice in the city, probably in the Serapeum precinct given the provenance of the just-mentioned dedication and statuette from there and the frequent iconographical associations between "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in Alexandrian coins.[20] Alexandria, then, clearly emerges as the cult center and probably the birthplace of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, which is consonant with the three Alexandrians bearing his name (5, 6, 9).[21] For the Cynopolite nome, the chief centre of the Egyptian god Anubis, the onomastic evidence is more suggestive than the archaeological and the iconographical. Among the three individuals with a name based on Hermanubis (11, 15, 16), there stands out the father of an underage priest of "Anubis, Leto and associated gods" in the Cynopolite village of Laura (15). Since priesthood was usually hereditary, the father Hermanubis was probably himself a priest of these gods. This onomastic connection of Hermanubis with the Cynopolite nome also has an echo in the iconography: one or two Alexandrian coins personify the Cynopolite nome with a representation of the anthropomorphic "Hermanubis" on their reverse (LIMC nos. 3, 22).

The name Hermanubis is found in papyri from various areas of Egypt, but most individuals with this name are from Alexandria or the Cynopolite nome. Alexandria is considered the cult center and likely birthplace of the anthropomorphic version of Hermanubis. The Cynopolite nome has less archaeological evidence but is connected through onomastic and iconographic associations. One Alexandrian coin even personifies the Cynopolite nome with an image of Hermanubis on the reverse.

conversation.content: summarise this: Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome with Hermanubis, without implying any relationship between the two. An acting epistrategus named Hermanubis is also attested in Alexandria, and there are associations between Hermanubis and Sarapis in iconography. A female name, Ἑρμανουβίαινα, referring to a citizen of Alexandria, was found in a document from 291 CE. There are various numismatic and iconographical representations of Hermanubis, but their significance is not fully clear.

Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The suffix -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, making the combination of Ἑρμάνουβιϲ and -άμμων unlikely to have a specific significance. Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more difficult to explain, but may simply be a combination of the god of the nome (Heracles) with Hermanubis. There are numismatic representations of "Hermanubis" with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon, and a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius shows jugate busts of Heracles and Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not occur in Egyptian documents, but is seen in a Macedonian inscription. conversation.content: summarise this: The divine name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a handful of epigraphic and literary sources, mostly of the Roman period.[2] Plutarch cites the name as a designation of Anubis in his underworldly aspect (De Is. et Os. 375e), while Porphyry refers to Hermanubis as ϲύνθετοϲ, "composite," and μιξέλλην, "half-Greek" (De imaginibus fr. 8, p. 18.1–2 Bidez). The name has been restored in a second-century BC dedicatory inscription from Delos (ID 2156.2 [Ἑρ]μανού[βιδι νικ]ηφόρωι), which would be its earliest attestation, but otherwise it appears in three inscriptions of the Roman period, two from Egypt and one from Thessalonike (see below). It is clear that the name is a result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes, which is well attested in a number of literary, epigraphic, and artistic sources.[3] Although Hermes was traditionally equated with the Egyptian Thoth, his function as psychopompos encouraged his association with Anubis given the latter's comparable funerary role in Egyptian religion as embalmer and guardian of the dead and as leader of the deceased to the tribunal of Osiris. This assimilation resulted in widespread Graeco-Roman representations of the canine-headed Anubis with attributes of the Greek Hermes, such as the distinctive staff known as the kerykeion or winged sandals.[4] As far as I know, none of these representations whose provenance is known was found in Egypt, though this may be due to mere chance.[5] But in Roman Alexandria there emerges a new iconographical type, well represented in coins and sculpture, in which a fully anthropomorphic young god is flanked by a dog and holds the same attributes as the said Anubis, in addition to wearing the calathos headdress.[6] It is this type that art historians have traditionally labeled "Hermanubis." In making this identification, they have been encouraged by Porphyry's statement about the god's "composite" and "half-Hellenic" character. However, it is important to stress that the reference to the fully anthropomorphic type as "Hermanubis" is only a hypothetical convention, and that not a single of the numerous representations of this type bears a legend or inscription identifying it as such.[7] I will return to this question at the end of the paper in light of the onomastic evidence.

The name "Hermanubis" is known from a few sources, mostly from the Roman period, and is believed to be the result of the assimilation of the Egyptian god Anubis to the Greek god Hermes. This resulted in representations of Anubis with attributes of Hermes. In Roman Alexandria, a new iconographical type emerged featuring a fully anthropomorphic young god flanked by a dog and holding the same attributes as Anubis, which art historians have labeled "Hermanubis." However, this identification is only a hypothetical convention, and there is no inscription identifying the representations as such.

conversation.content: summarise this: Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

The article discusses the origin and parallels of the Graeco-Roman god Hermanubis, a syncretic deity combining the features of Anubis and Hermes. While this combination was not common in traditional Greek religion, parallels can be found in earlier periods and in Egyptian religion. The article presents various literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes, and discusses the possible origin of the name Hermanubis.

This article discusses the personal name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, which is a polytheophoric name combining the names of two Roman deities, but is special because it refers to a specific deity that is independently attested. The article provides a summary of what is known about the god Hermanubis, and compares the onomastic evidence with his iconographical and documentary attestations.
The name Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is known from a few sources dating back to the Roman period. It combines the gods Hermes and Anubis, who were associated due to their respective roles as psychopompos and embalmer/guardian of the dead. This assimilation resulted in artistic representations of a canine-headed Anubis with Hermes’ attributes, and later, a fully anthropomorphic young god with a dog and Hermes’ attributes. The latter type is commonly referred to as “Hermanubis,” but this label is hypothetical and not backed up by any inscriptions or legends.
There are multiple forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis in Egyptian papyri and inscriptions. The form “Hermanubis” is simple replication of the god’s name without alteration. In one instance, a female nurse has the name “Hermanoubis” in the nominative form which is unusual for feminine theophoric names. It is suggested that the element “-ανουβιϲ” might have been conflated with Greek feminine names. There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: “Hermanoubās” and “Hermanoubiōn”. These suffixes were commonly used for personal names based on the Egyptian god Anubis. In a business letter, the two forms are used interchangeably to designate the same individual with “Hermanoubās” likely being a hypocoristic of “Hermanoubiōn”.
The name Hermanubis is modified with different suffixes to differentiate it from other polytheophoric names that join two divine names without modifying the original suffix. The concept of Hermanubis as a single god is reflected in personal names that join his name with that of other gods. These names should not be analyzed as triple theophoric names as they only imply the combination of two gods. This is not an exception to the usual rule that polytheophoric names combine no more than two deities.
The majority of names based on Hermanubis are found in papyri from the second and third centuries AD. The earliest example dates back to AD 94, but the name is abbreviated. There are a total of 19 instances of the name, with eight from the second century, eight from the third, and three from the fourth. The name disappears from evidence after the fourth century. This chronological distribution corresponds with the iconographical representations of the fully anthropomorphic god known as “Hermanubis,” with most representations from the second and third centuries.
Hermanubis names are found in Egyptian papyri, mostly from Alexandrian and Cynopolite regions. Alexandria is believed to be the birthplace and cult center of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis, as evidenced by archaeological findings and iconography. The Cynopolite nome also has connections to Hermanubis through onomastic evidence and iconography. A father of an underage priest of Anubis in Cynopolite village is believed to have been a priest of the associated gods.
This article discusses an onomastic survey that reveals three conclusions about the use of names based on the god Hermanubis in Roman Egypt. Firstly, unlike other polytheophoric names, Hermanubis names refer to a specific and independently attested god. Secondly, the chronological and geographical overlap between the onomastic evidence and representations of the fully anthropomorphic Alexandrian god supports the designation of the latter as “Hermanubis”. Finally, the connection of Hermanubis with Cynopolis and a priest of Anubis suggests that he continued to be closely associated with the traditional Anubis. Therefore, it may not be necessary to separate the traditional funerary Anubis from Hermanubis too forcefully.
The name Hermanubis is found outside of Egypt in a Macedonian inscription dating to the imperial period, spelled differently from the Egyptian form. It is likely related to the cult of Hermanubis, which was also popular in Thessalonike and Carthage during the Roman period. This suggests that the cult enjoyed popularity outside of its original home.

The passage cites several instances of the name Hermanubis from various sources, including inscriptions from Egypt, Macedonia, and Germany. Additionally, the author notes two literary references to the name, one from Gregory of Nazianzus’ autobiography and another from an unknown source. The passage from Gregory’s autobiography describes a failed coup attempt and names and criticizes some Egyptian sailors who were instructed to spy on Gregory by the bishop of Alexandria.

First of all came the spies, like those once sent forth
by the father of Israel, the chosen land –

Paul Gallay argues that the names mentioned in 838-839 are fictional and meant to satire the Egyptians and their past animal worship. Most of the names are typically Egyptian, but the occurrence of Anubis near Hermanubis suggests they are equivalent. The use of the adjective “kunodeis” in 840 does not necessarily mean Hermanubis is a canine-headed god, as it was likely only triggered by the name Anubis.
A literary work uses the name Hermanubis for satire. An anonymous Greek poem in the Greek Anthology criticizes a strategos, but is poorly executed.
Νῦν ὁ ϲτρατηγὸϲ Ἑρμανούβηϲ ἐγένετο
κύων ἀδελφοὺϲ ϲυλλαβὼν Ἑρμᾶϲ δύο
ἀϲημοκλέπταϲ ϲυνδεθένταϲ ϲχοινίῳ,
4ψυχροὺϲ ἀώρουϲ Ταρταρίουϲ τε δαίμοναϲ.
οὐκ οἶδα χῶρον τοῦ τρόπου κατήγορον·
τρόπον δὲ χώρου τὸν κατήγορον λέγω.
The strategos Hermanoubes turned into a dog after capturing two thieves. The speaker believes that a person’s character reveals more about them than their location.
The name “Hermanoubes” is not found in any document, and some suggest it should be “Hermanoubis” instead. The context of the poem is unclear, as it is uncertain whether Hermanoubes is the subject or predicate of the verb “egento.” If it is the former, the biting satire is enhanced by the association of his name with Anubis the dog and Hermes the thief. The meaning of “kyon” as an insult or a reference to protective duties is also unclear, as is the nature of the relationship between the strategos and the two thievish Hermeses.
The double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in earlier periods, such as the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ, but this implies the paradoxical union of two different gods, Hermes and Aphrodite, rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected in various sources, but the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis is uncertain. The appellation “Hermanubis” was not necessarily given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features. The accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ is used, and the sender of a letter mentioning Hermanubis is writing from Alexandria. Greek personal names were marked for gender in certain ways, and there are various suffixes used to indicate male and female names.
There are three exceptions to the rule, where place names end in -ηράκλειοϲ or -απολλώνιοϲ.
The ending “-άμμων” was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, so the combination of “Ἑρμάνουβιϲ” is not significant. “Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ” is more difficult to explain and may simply be a juxtaposition of two gods without a specific meaning. There are numismatic representations of “Hermanubis” with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon. The form “Ἑρμανούβιοϲ” does not appear in Egyptian documents but is found in a Macedonian inscription. On the associations of “Hermanubis” and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990. The female name “Ἑρμανουβίαινα” has been attested in a document from Alexandria. Further research on the iconography of Hermanubis is needed.
The passage discusses a satirical element in the accumulation of Greek names with Egyptian animal gods. It also mentions Gregory’s contrast between Egypt’s animal worship in the past and its conversion to Christianity. A few references to Greek personal names and their origins in nicknames are also included. The Works Cited section provides further sources on topics such as Egyptian religion, onomastics, and Gregory of Nazianzus.

conversation.content: summarise this: Notes See Benaissa 2009. Although it was not common in traditional Greek religion to combine the names of two gods in this manner, the double determination of Hermanubis has some formal parallels in the earlier period. The most obvious is the god Ἑρμαφρόδιτοϲ (see Ajootian 1990), attested from the fourth century BC onwards, but his name implies the paradoxical union of two different gods (Hermes and Aphrodite) rather than an assimilation in the manner of Hermanubis. A more apt parallel is provided by Ζηνοποϲειδῶν, an epiclesis of the Carian god Zeus Osogoa, who received the additional determination "Poseidon" as a result of his representation with features such as the trident (see Blümel 1987, 128). In Egyptian religion, the tendency to unite the names of two gods was long established and is well known (cf. Leclant 1975). A comparable form to Hermanubis from the Roman period is Ἡλιοϲέραπιϲ, which is not attested as a personal name (pace Hopfner 1946, 45). Schwartz 1947 also postulates a syncretic funerary god Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, but this is based purely on the iconographical evidence of some seals, without any support from textual sources (the personal name Ἑρμηρακλῆϲ, two instances of which have emerged since Schwartz's thesis, could be simply an example of a polytheophoric name and need not imply the recognition of an actual god of that name). The literary and epigraphic sources associating Anubis with Hermes are collected by Grenier 1977, 53–59, 95–98. Bernand, Inscriptions métriques n. 73 (Abydos; I–II) = GVI 1090, should also be added, as the Κυλλήνιοϲ Ἑρμῆϲ (9) leading the deceased to serve Osiris of Abydos is implicitly conflated with Anubis (see Dunand 1975, 158). Kákosy 1990, 145 points to some pre-Ptolemaic Egyptian statuettes, in which the feet or teeth of Thoth are modeled as jackal heads, as evidence that the later rapprochement of Anubis and Hermes was based on the earlier assimilation of Thoth to Anubis; but although Thoth and Anubis were closely associated in funerary contexts, I am not persuaded that these statuettes "wollten sicher den synkretischen Gott Thoth-Anubis darstellen" or that they are relevant to the question of the origin of the Graeco-Roman Hermanubis. See Leclant 1981, 871, and the references in Grenier 1977, 137–138. In the amulet published in Bonner 1950, n. 36 (Plate II) = LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 19, Anubis is described as holding in his right hand "a tall scepter resembling a Roman military standard, with palm leaves at top, and two garlands, the lower with ties" (Bonner 1950, 259). But this looks to me like a version of the kerykeion-cum-palm known from a number of coins of the fully anthropomorphic Hermanubis; see Grenier 1990, 265, and cf. the coins under 8(a). Whether the appellation "Hermanubis" was given to the canine-headed Anubis with Hermetic features is uncertain; Apuleius, Met. XI 11, refers to the god attolens canis cernices arduas and laena caduceum gerens simply as "Anubis." LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 13, found in Carthage or Cherchel, is the only representation for which an Alexandrian origin has been postulated, but on no firm basis (see Picard 1956, 176–179, who assigns to it an Alexandrian provenance and a date in the third century BC on the basis of the floral decoration). See Grenier 1990. Cf. Leclant 1981, 873. On "direct theonymy" see Parker 2000, 57–8, with further bibliography. For the accentuation Ἑρμάνουβιϲ rather than Ἑρμανοῦβιϲ (Preisigke and some editors), see Clarysse 1997, 180. While the letter was found in the Fayum, the sender is clearly writing from Alexandria; cf. Bagnall and Cribiore 2006, 389–390. For some observations on the marking of gender in Greek personal names, see Davies 2000, 20–21. Cf. Gignac, Grammar, II 55–57; Mayser, Grammatik, I.2 22–23. For masculine names in -ιϲ, -ιδοϲ/-ιοϲ and feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ, see Pape-Benseler, Wörterbuch der griechischen Eigennamen3, xviii-xix. See e.g. Preisigke, Namenbuch, 33–34; Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 34–35. See e.g. the "index des suffixes" in Masson 1990, II 632–633 s.v. -ᾶϲ ("suffixe d'hypocoristique et de sobriquet masculin").

The article discusses the naming and origins of the god Hermanubis, a fusion of the Greek god Hermes and the Egyptian god Anubis. While the combination of two gods' names was not common in Greek religion, it had parallels in earlier forms of worship. The article also explores the association between Anubis and Hermes in literary and epigraphic sources and examines various representations of the deity in art. Lastly, the article discusses the gender and suffixes used in Greek personal names.

conversation.content: summarise this: The ending -άμμων was attached to the names of most deities that appear in theophoric names (see Dunand 1963), so that its union with Ἑρμάνουβιϲ is unlikely to have a specific significance. One may adduce some numismatic representations in which "Hermanubis" is shown with a radiating crown and the horn of Ammon; see LIMC V s.v. Hermanubis nos. 10a, b. The name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is more intriguing and difficult to account for. If the papyrus is from the Heracleopolite nome as the ed. princ. suggests with a question mark (no internal evidence confirms this), the name may simply juxtapose the chief god of the nome (Heracles = Egyptian Harsenuphis) with Hermanubis, without necessarily implying an affinity between the two. For what it is worth, a coin from the reign of Antoninus Pius (Milne, Catalogue of Alexandrian Coins 1678 [Plate II]) shows jugate busts of Heracles and "Hermanubis." For a representation of the dog-headed Anubis with a club, see LIMC I s.v. Anubis n. 35. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ does not actually occur in Egyptian documents, though Ἀνούβιοϲ is occasionally attested. The Macedonian inscription discussed below (22) is the only instance of the form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ. See Grenier 1990. On this inscription see Fraser 1972, II 413–414 n. 576. For another inscription from Egypt mentioning Hermanubis, see SB I 238. Fraser 1972, I 269. It is not clear to me to which of the statuettes in LIMC this corresponds (n. 21?). On the associations of "Hermanubis" and Sarapis in iconography, see Grenier 1990, 268. The acting epistrategus Hermanubis attested in 13 (and possibly 14) may also originate from Alexandria. Cf. Plut., De Is. et Os. 375e: Ἄνουβιϲ ... ὅτε καὶ Ἑρμάνουβιϲ ὀνομάζεται, τὸ μὲν ὡϲ τοῖϲ ἄνω τὸ δ᾿ ὡϲ τοῖϲ κάτω προϲήκων. Addendum, January 2010: The female name Ἑρμανουβίαινα (referring to an ἀϲτή, i.e. a citizen of Alexandria or one of the three Greek cities of Egypt) is now attested in P.Mich. inv. 1960.3 (17 March 291), published by L.H. Blumell, ZPE 165 (2008) 186–190. I have not been able to consult D. Stefanovic, "The Iconography of Hermanubis," in H. Györy (ed.), Aegyptus et Pannonia III. Acta Symposii anno 2004 (Budapest 2006) 271–276. For a recent text and translation of this work, see Lukinovich and Martingay 1997. Ch. Jungck's edition with commentary (Diss. Basel 1974) was not available to me.

The ending -άμμων was commonly added to the names of deities in theophoric names, so the combination of Ἑρμάνουβιϲ may not be significant. Some numismatic representations of "Hermanubis" show him with attributes of both Hermes and Ammon. The origin of the name Ἡρακλερμάνουβιϲ is unclear, but it could be a juxtaposition of the chief god of a nome with Hermanubis. The form Ἑρμανούβιοϲ is not found in Egyptian documents, but is attested in a Macedonian inscription. There is debate around the associations between Hermanubis and Sarapis in iconography, and an acting epistrategus Hermanubis is mentioned in Plutarch's De Is. et Os. The name Ἑρμανουβίαινα has also been found in a papyrus. Some related works were not available to the author.

conversation.content: summarise this: 	There are three forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, in addition to two "proper" polytheophoric names. (In four instances [1, 5, 17, 21] the ending of the name is abbreviated or not preserved.) The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times (2, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15), simply replicates the god's name without further ado, through the phenomenon of "direct theonymy" (the giving to humans of unaltered divine names) that became widespread in the Roman period.[8] In an odd instance (9) the form Ἑρμανουβιϲ in the nominative is borne by a woman, an Alexandrian nurse (ἡ τροφόϲ).[9] It is highly unusual for female theophoric names to be unmarked for gender in this way.[10] I suspect that because the element -ανουβιϲ in Ἑρμάνουβιϲ was often declined with a dental declension in -ιδ-, it might have been conflated with the similar declension of Greek feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ.[11] If this is correct, it may be preferable to read the nurse's name as an oxytone (Ἑρμανουβίϲ). There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (six instances: 3, 4, 7, 8, 12, 20) and Ἑρμανουβίων (four instances: 3, 6, 18, 19). -ᾶϲ and -ίων were, in fact, the commonest Greek suffixes for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ.[12] It is interesting that in a business letter (3) the two forms Ἑρμανουβίων (l.38) and Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (l.41) are used interchangeably to designate the same individual. In this case, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ is probably a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων, since the suffix -ᾶϲ often served this purpose.[13]

The personal name based on the god Hermanubis can take three forms in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt, with two additional polytheophoric names. The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times, simply replicates the god's name. In an unusual instance, a woman bears the nominative form. Two further forms based on the god are Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ and Ἑρμανουβίων. These suffixes were common for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ. In one case, the two forms were used interchangeably to designate the same individual, with one likely being a hypocoristic of the other.

One of the forms, Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, is attested six times and replicates the god's name without alteration. The form Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, attested six times (2, 9, 11, 13, 14, 15), simply replicates the god's name without further ado, through the phenomenon of "direct theonymy" (the giving to humans of unaltered divine names) that became widespread in the Roman period.[8] In an odd instance (9) the form Ἑρμανουβιϲ in the nominative is borne by a woman, an Alexandrian nurse (ἡ τροφόϲ).[9] It is highly unusual for female theophoric names to be unmarked for gender in this way.[10] I suspect that because the element -ανουβιϲ in Ἑρμάνουβιϲ was often declined with a dental declension in -ιδ-, it might have been conflated with the similar declension of Greek feminine names in -ίϲ, -ίδοϲ.[11] If this is correct, it may be preferable to read the nurse's name as an oxytone (Ἑρμανουβίϲ). There are two further forms based on the god Hermanubis: Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (six instances: 3, 4, 7, 8, 12, 20) and Ἑρμανουβίων (four instances: 3, 6, 18, 19). -ᾶϲ and -ίων were, in fact, the commonest Greek suffixes for personal names based on the Egyptian god Ἄνουβιϲ.[12] It is interesting that in a business letter (3) the two forms Ἑρμανουβίων (l.38) and Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ (l.41) are used interchangeably to designate the same individual. In this case, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ is probably a hypocoristic of Ἑρμανουβίων, since the suffix -ᾶϲ often served this purpose.[13]

There are different forms of the personal name based on Hermanubis, including Ἑρμάνουβιϲ, Ἑρμανουβᾶϲ, and Ἑρμανουβίων, which were commonly used in papyri and inscriptions from Egypt. In some cases, the names were abbreviated or not preserved, and in one instance, a woman bore the nominative form of the name. It is possible that the feminine ending -ανουβιϲ was conflated with similar endings of Greek feminine names.
